meta.title: ESSAY DROP
meta.subtitle: B2 Writing Task
meta.question: "The use of smartphones should be limited for young people." Do you agree?

sectionBanners.title: INTRODUCTION
sectionBanners.desc: Hook the reader. State your position. Nothing more.
sectionBanners.narration: Part one: the Introduction. It has two jobs. First ‚Äî the hook. A powerful opening sentence that makes your reader immediately think about smartphones. Second ‚Äî the thesis. One sentence that tells the examiner exactly what your essay will argue. Two sentences. Two jobs. Nothing more.

parts.sub: Tell the reader what this essay will argue

sectionBanners.title:
BODY
PARAGRAPH
sectionBanners.desc: The engine room. Build your argument step by step.
sectionBanners.narration: Part two: the Body Paragraph. This is where you win marks. Every body paragraph is built from four sentences in exactly this order. First ‚Äî the claim. Then ‚Äî the reason. Then ‚Äî an example. Finally ‚Äî the result. Four moves. Watch each one build on screen.

sectionBanners.title: CONCLUSION
sectionBanners.desc: Summarise your argument. Deliver your final position.
sectionBanners.narration: Part three: the Conclusion. No new information. Simply summarise what you have argued and give your final, clear verdict on whether smartphones should be limited. End with confidence.

scenes.narration: Here is your essay question for today. The use of smartphones should be limited for young people. Do you agree? By the end of this lesson, you will know exactly how to write this.

scenes.headline: WHAT IS AN ESSAY?
scenes.body: A formal, structured discussion ‚Äî not a story, not a chat. Give your opinion on whether smartphones should be limited, backed up with reasons.
scenes.narration: So what is an essay? An essay is a formal, structured discussion. Not a story, not a list. You give your opinion on whether smartphones should be limited, and you back it up with evidence.

scenes.headline: 3 PARTS.
scenes.body: Every B2 essay is built from three parts. Each one has a job. Watch ‚Äî one at a time.
scenes.narration: Every B2 essay is built from three parts. Each part has one job. Watch them arrive ‚Äî one at a time.

scenes.headline: THE HOOK
scenes.body: Start with something that makes the reader think about smartphones.
scenes.narration: The hook is your very first sentence. For the smartphone essay, open with something powerful that makes the reader stop and think. Here are five hook phrases you can use right now.

scenes.headline: THESIS
scenes.body: Tell the reader what the essay will do. One clear aim.
scenes.narration: The thesis is your second sentence. It sets the aim of the whole essay. Here are three thesis structures that work perfectly for this question.

scenes.annNote: Signals which point you are making. Always followed by a comma.
scenes.narration: The very first word you write in your body paragraph is the listing word. Firstly ‚Äî capital F, comma. This single word positions your argument on the page.

scenes.annNote: Makes clear this is YOUR view. Signals critical thinking to the examiner.
scenes.narration: Now add your opinion phrase immediately after. It seems to me that. This phrase tells the examiner that what follows is your own considered view.

scenes.annNote: One specific point about smartphones. Argue it well.
scenes.narration: And now the claim itself ‚Äî the actual point about smartphones. Three moves combined: listing word, opinion phrase, claim. That is sentence one, complete.

scenes.annNote: You made a claim. Now explain WHY. Always link back to smartphones.
scenes.narration: Sentence two gives the reason. This is because ‚Äî and then WHY your claim is true. Notice how the new sentence lands directly on the growing paragraph.

scenes.annNote: Real-world evidence proves your point and impresses the examiner.
scenes.narration: Sentence three brings in your example. For instance. A real-world case ‚Äî France banning phones ‚Äî proves the point and shows you can think beyond the classroom.

scenes.annNote: Draw a conclusion from your evidence. Close the paragraph with impact.
scenes.narration: And the final sentence seals the paragraph. As a result. Four sentences. A claim, a reason, an example, and a result. That is a complete B2 body paragraph.

scenes.headline: CONCLUSION
scenes.body: No new ideas. Summarise your argument and give your final verdict on smartphones.
scenes.narration: And finally ‚Äî the conclusion. No new ideas. Summarise everything you have argued and give your final verdict on whether smartphones should be limited. End with confidence.

items.full: Nowadays, smartphones are used by millions of young people around the world every single day.
In recent years, there has been a growing debate about whether young people should have unlimited access to their phones.
It is widely believed that smartphone use has changed the way young people learn, communicate and relax.
Many people argue that excessive smartphone use is one of the most serious challenges facing young people today.

items.key: It is impossible to deny that
items.full: It is impossible to deny that smartphones play a significant role in the daily lives of young people.
This essay will discuss the main advantages and disadvantages of limiting smartphone use for young people.

items.key: In this essay, I will examine
items.full: In this essay, I will examine both sides of the argument before giving my personal opinion.

items.key: The aim of this essay is to
items.full: The aim of this essay is to consider whether limiting smartphones would truly benefit young people.
To sum up, limiting smartphones has both real advantages and some drawbacks for young people.
Overall, I believe that the benefits of limiting screen time outweigh the drawbacks for young people.
All things considered, restricting smartphone use can be positive if it is done in a balanced and fair way.
In conclusion, I firmly believe that setting clear limits on smartphone use would help young people perform better at school and lead healthier lives.
